Introduction

Bilirubin is a yellow pigment produced from the breakdown of heme-containing proteins (primarily hemoglobin).  Although it can function as an antioxidant at physiologic levels (ie, bilirubin-biliverdin redox cycle), bilirubin can be toxic in excess.  Bilirubin metabolism is a multistep process that is essential for maintaining normal physiologic levels and preventing toxic accumulation of bilirubin.

Bilirubin metabolism



Bilirubin production and metabolism involve production, metabolism, and excretion.

Bilirubin production



Approximately 80% of bilirubin is a by-product of hemoglobin metabolism in senescent red blood cells.  The remaining 20% is a by-product of the metabolism of other heme-containing proteins (eg, myoglobin).  The first step in bilirubin formation is the conversion of heme to biliverdin by the enzyme heme oxygenase.  Next, biliverdin is reduced to unconjugated bilirubin (indirect bilirubin) by the enzyme biliverdin reductase.  Because unconjugated bilirubin is lipophilic, it is not water-soluble and must bind albumin for transport to the liver.

Bilirubin metabolism



Within the liver, bilirubin is conjugated to glucuronic acid by the hepatic enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, making it water-soluble (

figure 1
).  Conjugated bilirubin is transported into the biliary tract for secretion into the small intestine as bile.

Bilirubin excretion



Once conjugated, bilirubin is water-soluble and cannot be reabsorbed through the lipid membrane of the intestinal epithelium.  Instead, conjugated bilirubin remains in the intestinal lumen, where it is reduced to urobilinogen by intestinal bacteria.  Most urobilinogen is further processed for excretion in the stool; however, some urobilinogen is reabsorbed and reenters the circulation, where it can be transported to the liver (ie, enterohepatic circulation) or kidneys (for excretion in urine).

Disorders of bilirubin metabolism



Any disruption in bilirubin metabolism can lead to bilirubin accumulation in the serum (hyperbilirubinemia).  Hyperbilirubinemia typically manifests as jaundice (yellow discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes) and can be confirmed with laboratory evaluation (eg, total serum bilirubin level >1 mg/dL).  If hyperbilirubinemia is present, identifying the predominant type of bilirubin (eg, conjugated or unconjugated) in the plasma is generally the first step in identifying the underlying cause (

figure 2
).

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia



Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is characterized by a serum conjugated (direct) bilirubin level <1 mg/dL or <20% of total serum bilirubin and can occur due to:



  • Excessive bilirubin production (eg, hemolysis, blood extravasation into tissues leading to destruction by tissue macrophages).
  • Impaired hepatic bilirubin uptake:  Occurs due to impaired hepatic blood flow (eg, congestive heart failure, portosystemic shunt) or use of medications that may compete with bilirubin for hepatic uptake (eg, rifampin).
  • Impaired bilirubin conjugation:  Occurs due to impaired UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity, as follows:
    • Crigler-Najjar syndrome:  Rare autosomal recessive disorder in which a mutation within the coding sequence of the gene for UDP-glucuronosyltransferase leads to reduced enzyme activity.  Complete loss of enzyme activity (eg, Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1) can lead to severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia within the first few days of birth that can cause permanent neurologic deficits.
    • Gilbert syndrome:  Benign autosomal recessive disorder in which a mutation in the promoter sequence of the gene for UDP-glucuronosyltransferase results in mildly reduced enzyme levels.  This typically presents in adolescence with episodic jaundice triggered by stress.  Patients are generally asymptomatic between episodes.

Conjugated (direct) hyperbilirubinemia



Conjugated (direct) hyperbilirubinemia is characterized by a serum conjugated (direct)  bilirubin level >1 mg/dL or >20% of total serum bilirubin and can occur due to any disruption in bilirubin metabolism after conjugation in the liver.  Additional laboratory testing (eg, aspartate aminotransferase [AST], alanine aminotransferase [ALT], alkaline phosphatase) is often necessary to determine the underlying cause, as follows:



  • Impaired transport of conjugated bilirubin into (ie, enterohepatic circulation) or out of (eg, Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome) the liver:  These conditions are characterized by normal AST, ALT, and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Physical obstruction of biliary flow (eg, cholelithiasis, postsurgical strictures, malignancy, primary sclerosing cholangitis):  These conditions tend to have significantly elevated alkaline phosphatase levels (ie, cholestatic pattern of liver injury).
  • Other clinical conditions leading to hepatic injury (eg, viral hepatitis, medication toxicity, alcoholic hepatitis).  These conditions are characterized by predominantly elevated AST and ALT  levels.


These conditions are discussed in separate dedicated articles.

Summary



Bilirubin is a yellow pigment produced from the breakdown of heme-containing proteins (primarily hemoglobin).  Although it can function as an antioxidant at physiologic levels (ie, bilirubin-biliverdin redox cycle), bilirubin can be toxic in excess.  Bilirubin metabolism is a multistep process that is essential in maintaining normal physiologic levels and preventing toxic accumulation of bilirubin.  If hyperbilirubinemia is present, recognizing the predominant form of bilirubin (eg, conjugated or unconjugated) in the plasma helps identify the underlying cause.
